title: AB 933
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature enacted the 24/7 Sobriety program in California to qualify for FAST Act grant funding and NHTSA funding. This program aims to deter impaired driving by targeting high-risk offenders. A new section, 23582.5, is added to the Vehicle Code to implement the program. The Legislature enacted the 24/7 Sobriety program in California to qualify for FAST Act grant funding and NHTSA funding. A new section, 23582.5, is added to the Vehicle Code, allowing courts to order participation in the program for individuals convicted of DUI offenses. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program to obtain a restricted driving privilege if they committed a violation within 10 years of a DUI conviction. Participation in the program is required for a minimum of one year. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program for a minimum of one year. The program requires abstaining from alcohol or controlled substances, undergoing breath testing at least twice daily, and facing immediate sanctions for violations. The program must be evidence-based, meeting specific criteria for effectiveness. The 24/7 Sobriety program produces positive results attributed to the program itself, peer-reviewed and endorsed by federal agencies. Participants may also be required to join other DUI programs, with testing locations prioritizing timely sanctions. Program costs are based on ability to pay. The court may impose a program of up to 180 days in length for defendants who test positive for alcohol or drugs. The Office of Traffic Safety must include provisions for the 24/7 Sobriety program in its highway safety plan. The department will collect data on participant demographics, case history, testing information, and fees. Section 1808 of the Vehicle Code is amended. The department will establish uniform collection and reporting of participant data including demographic information, case history, testing details, and fees. Section 1808 of the Vehicle Code is amended to allow public inspection of certain records, except for those involving fault in accidents. The department in Sacramento discloses abstracts of convictions and accident reports within specific time frames. Suspensions and revocations of driving privileges are also disclosed for a certain period. Judicially set aside or stayed suspensions or revocations are not disclosed. The department in Sacramento discloses convictions and accident reports within specific time frames. Personal information is not disclosed unless in compliance with the Driver’s Privacy Protection Act. Convictions of specific offenses are disclosed to courts and law enforcement agencies for penalty imposition purposes. The department in Sacramento discloses convictions of specific offenses to courts and law enforcement agencies for penalty imposition purposes. Consent for the use of a driver's license number by insurance agents or employers is presumed if provided for insurance coverage or employment eligibility. Insurance agents or brokers can transmit motor vehicle records for specific purposes authorized by law. They are not liable for how the recipient handles the records. Prior to sharing records with an insurer without a written agreement, the agent must ensure the insurer will handle the records according to state and federal laws on privacy and fair credit reporting.
